title: "Light Therapy, Serotonin and Sugar: Treating Seasonal Affective Disorder"
first_phrase: This text explores the connection between Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD), sleep patterns, melatonin levels, and light therapy. The first half discusses how SAD affects sleep/wake patterns and melatonin production, leading to delayed sleep and difficulty waking up. Researchers at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City found that sunrise and sunset light therapy can help alleviate these symptoms. The second half delves into the relationship between serotonin, sugar consumption, and the brain. Low levels of serotonin may cause depression, disrupt the appetite mechanism, and lead to eating disorders. Insulin, produced in response to sugar intake, can increase tryptophan levels in the brain and potentially alleviate these symptoms.
content: However, they get worse again when given melatonin capsules. (Rosenthal, N.E, et al., 'Seasonal Affective Disorder and Phototherapy', Ann. New York Acad. Sci: 435; 260-267, 1985) Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that conveys the positive sensations of satiety, satisfaction and relaxation. It regulates appetite and when converted to melatonin helps us to sleep. A deficiency of Serotonin in the brain can cause endogenous depression, upsets the appetite mechanism and may lead to obesity or other eating disorders such as anorexia and bulimia nervosa. Sugar consumption stimulates the body to produce insulin, a hormone which transports glucose, fatty acids and amino acids (except tryptophan) into body cells. Thus insulin speeds up the absorption of amino acids other than tryptophan. Normally, tryptophan must compete with other amino acids for entry into the brain, but insulin eliminates the competition, allowing tryptophan levels to rise in the brain.
last_phrase: In conclusion, maintaining a balanced diet that includes tryptophan-rich foods, as well as adequate vitamin B6 and magnesium, can positively impact serotonin levels, leading to improved mood and appetite regulation. Limiting sugar consumption and insulin spikes can also prevent sugar addiction and weight gain. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized recommendations and treatment for depression and other disorders.
